title-group.article-title: Noise reduction through elastically restrained sandwich polycarbonate window pane into rectangular cavity

article-meta.aff: 1Graduate School of Engineering, Hiroshima University, Japan
2Faculty of Engineering, Hiroshima Kokusai Gakuin University, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Shen Min, Graduate School of Engineering, Hiroshima University, 1-4-1 Kagamiyama, Higashi-Hiroshima, 739-8527, Japan Email: shenmin18@hiroshima-u.ac.jp

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In the automobile industry, the use of the polycarbonate (PC) window pane is well developed. Unfortunately, the demand for greater mechanical performance will result in serious noise problems because of its high rate of stiffness to low weight. There is a need to design a PC window pane with a superior passive acoustical insulating property for automobile consumer comfort. This paper investigates the noise transmission characteristics of an elastically supported sandwich PC pane into a rectangular cavity using a modal analysis combination with compact matrix formulation. This approach made it easier to investigate the coupled structural-cavity systems. The numerical results reveal that an improvement in noise reduction can be realized by the appropriate selection of structural parameters such as the damping of core, density of viscoelastic core material and the thickness of the face plate.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Polycarbonate (PC) material is used as a substitute glass material for window panes in automobile industries because of its high strength and stiffness ratio to weight. However, noise transmits easily and directly from the outside into the interior cabin through the light window pane. Past studies have demonstrated that a viscoelastic core sandwich structure is an efficient way of dissipating vibration energy and useful for noise reduction. In order to design a new type of PC pane with a superior passive acoustical insulating property, it is of great interest to investigate sound transmission characteristics through a finite sandwich PC pane into a cavity.

The actual automobile body construction is too complicated for a detailed mathematical treatment; therefore a simplified interior acoustic enclosure is taken as a rectangular cavity in this paper. A PC window pane, mounted in one surface, represents the flexible panel, rubber being used for the edge support. The pane forms one flexible wall of a rectangular interior cavity, and three other walls of the cavity are regarded as acoustically rigid. The model to be computed is shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Geometry of the cavity backed by flexible pane.

The interaction of the panel-cavity coupled system has been studied extensively over the past several decades. Junger and Feit (1985) first briefly introduced interaction between acoustic space and the structural vibration problem. Since then Lyon and Smith (1965), Pretlove (1965, 1996), Guy and Bhattacharya (1973) and Guy (1979) directed at improving the understanding of sound transmission through panels into cavities. They provided an exact solution using the classical Laplace and Fourier transform method. Dowell et al. (1977) provided a general theory for coupled responses in terms of the modal characteristics and mode shapes of the uncoupled panel and cavity systems. Pan et al. (1989) analyzed the coupled response under both controlled and uncontrolled conditions to minimize noise transmitted into the cavity. Li and Cheng. (2007) analyzed the rectangular-like cavity with a titled wall. However, theoretical models mentioned above are mainly limited to plates being simply supported on four edges. Transverse vibrations of rectangular plates with various boundary conditions have been extensively studied in the literature, as reviewed by Leissa (1969). Li et al. (2009) presented an exact series solution for the transverse vibration of rectangular plates generally with boundary supports. Du et al. (2011) improved convergence of the Fourier series representation for transverse vibration of generally supported rectangular plates.

Vaicaitis (1978) considered noise transmission through a sandwich plate with a viscoelatic constrained layer into a cavity. In his model, also four edges of the plate were simply supported. Based on this model, Narayanan and Shanbhag (1981a,b) investigated the sound transmission characteristics of a cavity backed by sandwich panels. In this work, two opposite edges of the plate are assumed to be simply supported and the other two edges are assumed to be either fixed or simply supported. Huang and Ng (1998) and Rajaram et al. (2006) conducted experimental sound transmission loss studies extended to honeycomb sandwich panels.

In automobiles, panes are usually supported by rubber strips and stringers. The edge conditions should be taken as the elastically supported and described by appropriated boundary conditions. Analytical models for the sound transmission of panes also require a knowledge of boundaries’ conditions. This paper predicts the sound transmission through an elastically supported three-layer sandwich pane into a rectangular cavity by stationary random pressure excitations, and modal coupling analysis is included. The modal coupling analysis involves analysis of in-vacuo modal response of the sandwich pane and the blocked modal response of the cavity. Numerical examples have been given to determine the noise reduction for various core parameters, the phenomena of panel and cavity resonance can be readily identified from the final results.

sec.title: 2.1. Acoustical problem
sec.p: Consider the cavity occupies a volume V=abd, and the wall located at z=0 represents the flexible plate while the remaining walls are considered to be acoustically rigid as shown in Figure 1. The sound pressure pc inside the cavity is governed by the linear acoustic wave equation given by: (1)∇2pc-1c2∂2pc∂t2=0

The boundary conditions to be satisfied are: (2)∂pc∂n={-ρ∂2w∂t2onAF0onAR where w is the displacement of flexible wall, ρ and c are respectively the density and the wave speed of the fluid, AF is the flexible pane surface, AR is the acoustic rigid surface and n is the unit normal to the corresponding surface.
Equation (1) has rigid wall normal mode solutions Fneiωt,n=0,1,2… (or cavity mode shape functions) which satisfy the equations (3)∇2Fn+(ωnA/c)2Fn=0 on A=AF+AR

ωnA is the nth acoustic cavity resonance frequency and Fn is the natural mode of the cavity. According to the orthogonality of the cavity modes in the form (4)(1/V)∫vFnFrdV=MnAδrn where δrn is the Kronecker delta and MnA is the modal masses, the pressure inside the cavity can be expanded in terms of the cavity mode shape functions as (5)pc=ρc2∑nPnFn/MnA
The wave equation (1) can be transformed into a set of ordinary differential equations in time by using Green’s theorem in the form (6)∫v(pc∇2Fn-Fn∇2pc)dv=∫A(pc∂Fn∂n-Fn∂pc∂n)dA
By defining (7)Pn=(1/ρc2V)∫vpcFndv,Wn=(1/AF)∫AFwFndAF

The pressure coefficients pn in the acoustic normal mode expansion are determined by with considering wall absorption and air damping in the cavity, the detail reference Dowell et al. (1977) (8)p··n+2ζnAωnAp·n+ωnA2Pn=-(AF/v)w··n,n=0,1,2… (9)ωnA=ωijk=cπ(i2/a2)+(j2/b2)+(k2/d2) (10)ζnA=ζ1A(ω1A/ωnA)2 where ωnA is the cavity modal frequencies, ζnA is the each modal damping coefficient and ζ1A is the damping coefficient corresponding to the lowest non-zero cavity frequency ω1A. A dot(·) representing one differentiation with respect to time. (Dowell et al., 1977).

sec.title: 2.2. Structural response
sec.p: After eliminating the in-plane displacements u,v and neglecting the inertia forces in the x- and y- directions, the equation of motion for the transverse displacement can be reduced to the form (11)∇6w-g'(1+Y)∇4w+(μ/Dt)(∂2/∂t2)(∇2w-g'w) =1/Dt(∇2pt-g'p) whereg″=g*(1+iβ)=2G(1-v2)(1+iβ)/Eh1h2,∇4=∂4/∂x4+2(∂4/∂x2y2)+∂4/∂y4∇6=∂6/∂x6+3(∂6/∂x4y2)+3(∂6/∂x2y4)+∂6/∂y6,∇2=∂2/∂x2+∂2/∂y2

The response of the viscoelsatic core sandwich pane for a harmonic or stationary random pressure excitation can be expanded in terms of the normal modes as (12)w=∑qmϕm where ϕm are the forced damped normal modes and qm are the corresponding generalized co-ordinates.

For the edges x=±a/2 fixed, y=0 and y=b simply supported, the modes shape functions become (13)ϕm=ϕuv=∑r=13Crucos(λrx/a)sin(vπy/b) with the three boundary conditions (14)∑r=13Crcos(λra/2)=0(zero displacement) ∑r=13Crλrsin(λra/2)=0(zero slope) ∑r=13Crλr(λr2+(vπ/b)2)[λr2+(vπ/b)2+g″]λrsin(λra/2)=0(zero shear strain inxzplane in the core)

On expanding the determinant of the coefficient of the Cr″s, equating it to zero. The problem is to find the complex enginvalue λr″s by iterative interpolation methods and from these to solve the values of ωuv and ηuv which are the resonance frequency and the associated loss factor for a fixed supported condition (Mead, 1972): (15)ωuv2(1+iηuv)=Dμ{[λr2+(vπ/b)2]3+g″(1+Y)[λr2+(vπ/b)2]2λr2+(vπ/b)2+g″}

For the edges x=±a/2,y=0 and y=b simply supported, the results can be obtained in closed form with damped normal modes (16)ϕm=ϕuv=cos(uπx/a)sin(vπy/b) and complex natural frequencies (17)ωuv2(1+iηuv)=Dμ{[(uπ/a)2+(vπ/b)2]3+g″(1+Y)[(uπ/a)2+(vπ/b)2]2(uπ/a)2+(vπ/b)2+g″}

sec.title: 3.1. Coupled acoustic structural model
sec.p: By making use of the orthogonality property of the normal modes, the qm are governed by the equation (18)Mm[q··m+ωuv2(1+iηuv)qm]=Qcuv+Qeuv where Mm=∫0b∫-a/2a/2μϕuv2dxdy is the generalized mass, Qcuv=∫AFpϕuvdAF is the generalized forces of the cavity and Qeuv=-∫AFpeϕuvdAF is the generalized force of the external.

According to equation (8), equation (13) and equation (18), the coupled acoustic structural equations can be written in the form (19)p··n+2ζnAωnAp·n+ωnA2Pn=-∑m(AF/v)Lnmq··m (20)Mm[q··m+ωuv2(1+iηuv)qm] =ρc2AF∑n(PnLnm/MnA)+Qme (21)Lnm=∫0b∫-a/2a/2Fnϕuvdxdy

Where Lnm represents the coefficient corresponding to the acoustic-structural coupling. By extracting limited n number of cavity mode and m number of structural damped modes, the solution of the problem can be decoupled to a matrix eigenvalue problem. The pressure inside the cavity and the structural response of the panel are determined by a matrix inversion procedure equations (19) and (20) can be expressed in matrix form as (22)[[I][B1][0][I]][{P··}{q··}]+[[2ζnAωnA][0][0][0]][{P·}{q·}]+[[ωnA2][0][B2][ωuv2(1+iηuv)]][{P}{q}]=[{0}{Q}] where [I] is the n×n dimensional unit matrix, [B1] is the n×m dimensional matrix, and the ij element of the matrix is b1ij=(AF/V)Lij, [B2] is the m×n matrix, and the ij element of the matrix is b2ij=-(ρc2AF/MjAMis)Lji; {P} is the n×1 dimensional vectors of the pressure coefficients; {q} is the m×1 dimensional vectors of generalized co-ordinates qm.{Q} is m×1 dimensional vectors of external force vector and the mthelement is given by Qem=Qeuv/Muv.

sec.title: 3.2. Random loading
sec.p: For the analysis presented in this paper, the external pressure excitation was assumed to be Gaussian white noise for which the spectral density is S0, the input pressure cross power spectral density function can be written as (23)Spe(x1,y1;x2,y2;ω)=Sp(ω)rxy(x1,y1;x2,y2;ω) where rxy(x1,y1;x2,y2;ω)=1 is considered as the spectrum of the spatial correlation between pressures at locations (x1,y1) and (x2,y2) on the surface of the plate and Sp(ω)=S0 is the specified input pressure spectral density. The cross power spectral density between the generalized forces Qem and Qer corresponding to the mth and rth damped normal modes can be obtained as (24)SQmQr(ω)=Sp(ω)Imr(ω)/MmsMrs (25)Imr(ω)=∫0b∫-a/2a/2∫0b∫-a/2a/2rϕm(x1,y1)ϕr*(x2,y2)dx1dy1dx2dy2

From equations (24) and (25), the cross spectral density matrix of the generalized forces can be constructed as (26)[SQQ(ω)]=SP(ω)[I¯(ω)] where the mrth element of the acceptance matrix [I¯] is (27)Imr(ω)/(MmsMrs)

The cross spectral density matrix of the pressure coefficients and structural generalized co-ordinates can be presented as (28)[SAS(ω)]=[[Spp(ω)][Spq(ω)][Sqp(ω)][Sqq(ω)]]=[A][[0][0][0][SQQ(ω)]][A*]T where the superscript T indicates the matrix transpose and the asterisk again indicates the complex conjugate. (29)[A]=[[A1][A2][A3][A4]]

According to equations (28) and (29), the spectral density matrices are represented by (30)[Spp(ω)]=[A2][SQQ][A2*]T (31)[Sqq(ω)]=[A4][SQQ][A4*]T (32)[A2]=-ω2[znA]-1[B1][A4] (33)[A4]=[[Zuv]-ω2[B2][znA]-1[B1]]-1 (34)Zuv(ω)=ωuv2(1+iηuv)-ω2 (35)ZnA(ω)=ωnA2+2iζnAωnAω-ω2
[Zuv] and [ZnA] are diagonal matrices having m-dimensional elements and n-dimensional elements respectively.

Similarly, from equation (11) and (26) the power spectral density of the displacement wat point on the surface of the panel is given by (37)Sww(x,y,ω)={γ}[Sqq(ω)]{γ*}, where γ is an m-dimensional vector whose mth element is γm=ϕm(x,y).
The noise reduction at the centre of the pane is (38)NR=10log{SP(ω)r(0,b/2,ω)/Spcpc(0,b/2,0,ω)}
Hence, the noise reduction is then a function of the pane position chosen for the measurement of the back pressure and of the frequency.

sec.title: 4. Numerical results and discussion
sec.p:
The modal parameters of cavity and panel, considered in the calculation are presented in Table 1. The external pressure excitation is assumed to be a stationary white noise excitation Sp(ω)=S0, uniform with respect to the spatial panel. This paper considered two kinds of boundary conditions, the first is four edges simply supported, and the second is two edges assumed to be simply supported at y=0,b with the other two edges to be fixed supported at x=±a/2. In the case of vehicles, the interior noise generated by structural vibration is caused by the external sources predominating at low frequencies. Hence, the analytical frequency range has been restricted to 1000 Hz in this paper. Table 1.
Material properties of the polycarbonate pane-cavity system
Dimension of enclosure a = 0.44 m, b = 0.94 m, d = 0.625 m
Density of air ρa=1.21kg/m3
Speed of sound c = 330 m/s
Modulus elasticity of polycarbonate E=2.4×109N/m2
Poisson’s ratio Υ = 0.38
Density of face plate ρp=1200kg/m3
Density of core ρc=0.2ρp
Thickness of face plate h1 = h3 = 0.003 m
Thickness of core h2 = 0.006 m
Density of air ρa=1.21kg/m3

Table 2 presents the first 16 natural frequencies and damping of the rigid cavity and Table 3 presents the first 15 natural frequencies of the fixed supported plates and the modal loss factors, respectively. The components of the order n is the cavity mode, indicating the cavity mode shapes along the x,y and z directions, respectively denoted by the indices i, j, k. Similarly, the components of the order m is the forced damped normal modes of the pane, indicating the structural mode shapes along the x and y directions respectively denoted by the indices u, v. According to equation (21), the acoustic-structural modal coupling coefficients Lmn have non-zero values only for those combinations of (i + u) and (j + v) which are odd integers. The modal coupling analysis is considerably simpler and efficient in computation and plate characteristic functions represent plate modes more accurately and yield a more accurate estimation of noise transmission performance. Table 2.
Natural frequencies and damping of the cavity

9 (5,5) 357 0.020 448 0.118 877 0.192

Figure 2 compares the noise reductions of two edges fixed supported and simply supported on x=±a/2, with other parameters β=0.3,ζ1A=0.02. It is seen from Figure 2 that the location of the dips in the noise reduction curves occur mostly at the cavity resonant frequencies, which are almost independent of the boundary conditions. This is because excitation frequencies are near structural resonant frequencies, which are separated from cavity resonant frequencies, indicating a strong coupling between structural modes and cavity modes. Negative noise reduction can be observed from the graphs irrespective of the edge conditions. Figure 2.
Comparison noise reduction of edges fix supported and simply supported on x=±a/2, ○, cavity resonances □, structural resonances.

Figure 3 compares the noise transmission characteristics of the sandwich pane with respect to the shear modulus g* for edges simply and fixed supported on x=±a/2. It is seen from Figure 3 that further dips occur at structural resonance frequencies due to the lower shear modulus values corresponding to the two cases boundary conditions. The noise reduction curve has an obvious dip at 57 Hz corresponding to the structural resonance frequency of the pane and the damping layer can be used to improve the noise reduction near the structural resonant frequencies. Figure 3.
Effect of core shear modulus on noise reduction with edges fix supported on x=±a/2, other parameter Y=27,β=0.3 and ζ1A=0.002.

The fluctuations of noise reduction are also quite large and can be important in the transmission of noise which has a peaky power spectrum. The effect of a cavity on noise transmission is especially obvious when a thin pane is backed with a cavity. A sandwich pane is expected to have a low shear modulus so that shear waves, rather than bending waves, are dominant at the frequencies.

Figure 4 compares the power spectral densities of displacement for two cases boundary conditions variation with the shear parameter g*. For the fixed supported case, the resonance frequencies at which the structural response peak occurs are slightly shifted to the right than in the simply supported case. It is seen from Figure 4 that the dips of displacement power spectral density are lower, if the modal loss factor is higher according to Table 3. It is seen in Figure 3 that the noise is mostly transmitted into the cavity at the resonant frequencies and we can see from Figure 4 that the power displacement spectral has many peaks especially at the resonant frequencies. According to Table 3, the core shear parameter g* has significantly influence effects on resonant frequencies. Therefore, we should choose proper core shear parameter to ensure the noise reduction and improvement power displacement spectral. Figure 4.
Effects of core shear modulus on power spectral densities of displacement for two case boundary conditions.

Figure 5 compares the noise transmission characteristics of the sandwich pane with respect to the core loss factor β for edges simply and fixed supported on x=±a/2. It is seen from Figure 5 that the noise reduction is almost independent of the edge conditions. The noise reduction curve has an obvious dip at 57 Hz due to the structural resonance frequency. If β = 0 represents an elastic core, except dips at the cavity resonances, dips also occur corresponding to the structural resonances in the noise reduction curve. Interior noise in the structural resonance is strongly controlled by the vibration characteristic of the skin panels. Increasing β has little effect on noise reduction values at the cavity resonant frequencies. Figure 5.
Effect of core loss factor on noise reduction with edges fix supported on x=±a/2, other parameter Y=27,β=0.3 and ζ1A=0.002.

Figure 6 compares power spectral densities of displacement for two cases of boundary conditions variation with the core loss factor. It is seen from Figure 6 that there are more peaks than in the other two cases for β = 0, especially in the low frequency range obviously. The displacement power spectral densities are reduced with the core loss factor increasing. Figure 6.
Effects of core loss factor on power spectral densities of displacement for two case boundary conditions.

Figure 7 compares noise transmission characteristics of a sandwich pane for two cases of boundary conditions variation with geometric parameter Y. It is seen from Figure 7 that the pane noise reduction is improved on increasing the geometric parameter Y in low frequencies. We can see from Figure 7 that the noise transmission performances have many peaks because of pane structural resonant frequencies. According to Equation (17), the structural resonant frequencies are also determined by geometric parameter Y. Hence, proper geometric parameter should be chosen to ensure better noise transmission performance. There are dips in the noise reduction curves also corresponding to the cavity resonant frequencies. Figure 7.
Effect of geometric parameter on noise reduction with edges fix supported on x=±a/2, other parameter g* = 10, β = 0 and ζ1A = 0.02.

Figure 8 compares the displacement power spectral densities for two cases of boundary conditions variation with geometric parameter Y. It is seen from Figure 8, if the noise reduction curves exhibit dips at structural resonance frequencies, there are also peaks shown in the displacement power spectral curve. Figure 8.
Effects of core loss factor on power spectral densities of displacement for two case boundary conditions.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: The transmission of sound into a closed box through a single layer PC panel has been derived for comparison by coupled FEM-FEM models. According to the numerical results of noise reduction, the modification of a sandwich structure can be increased by the exciting source at a particular point depending on the power spectra of the forcing pressure. But the fluctuations of noise reduction are also quite large and can be important in the transmission of noises which are peaky on the power spectrum. Sound transmission performances are sensitive to both structural resonant frequencies and acoustic resonant frequencies. There is a possibility to decrease structural resonant frequencies using sandwich structure.

Increasing the viscoelastic core layer of a PC plate broadens the quadratic shape of each performance of noise reduction. This means that for more highly damped structures, the requirement exists for optimizing the viscoelastic material.

The core of a sandwich PC pane can be made from a more lightweight and less expensive material, while a PC face sheet bearing load capacity. This characteristic of sandwich structure can be utilized to design a practical PC pane with both good sound insulation properties and mechanical stiffness at a minimal weight. The sound transmission performance of sandwich panels can be much better than single-layer panels because of the core, the dynamic stiffness of which is strongly dependent on frequency.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

def.p: Total flexural rigidity of both face plate
Young's modulus of the face plate
Storage shear module of the damping core
Resultant transverse loading on the whole plate
Mass per unit area of the entire sandwich
Poisson's ratio of the face polycarbonate pane
